reviewText:
Many people complains that the graphichs are suck in this game, but I for one, what everyone like to say; it's not the graphic that counts!

Bought jus two weeks ago, and now I've hit 100+ Hours. The game's intetntion to be realistic, and sometimes it really hits that! I'm talking about the sword fight. It's the most realistic, fun, and challenging part of the game, and whenever I play some other game, I miss this fight system, because it literally ROCKS!!!

You can attack in 4 direction, based on the mouse movement (or keyboard, even you can set it to automatic like defense, but trust me, you don't want that, that's the biggest challenge in the game), and if you riding a horse, when you hit the enemy with your weapon the speed of impact counts. (It's a multiplier, you can get 300% more damage if you on a horse with full speed, and both the enemy and you are running towards each other.

The bow simulation is also perfect, it's one of the most close to the bow/crossbow simulation in the game world, just like sword dueling. I've been practicing with bows in real life, so I can say, Warband is SO CLOSE to the term of realistic. It's also a cookie that you can shoot with the bow from horseback in a different, awesome simulation system like none of the game developers implemented in their own game.

It's an RPG game, so that adds to the FUN. But if you buy it, (and I hope you do, because its developers are not the richest out there, so they need YOUR support to make their game better) expect some bugs, and WTF moments, like when you realize how hard is to get money at HIGH level, or attacking a bandit camp. The bandit lairs above level 40 is literally impossible. IMPOSSIBLE. I wish the developers would fix that.

And in online mode, Warband is like Counter Strike. (the equipment system I mean) You kill, you get money. You get killed, you lose your stuff. There are still more to be said about this game, but I'll let the others to do that! ;)

8/10 Game, I APPROVE.

reviewText:
Mount & Blade: Warband (along with its predecessor, Mount & Blade) is a game so unique it is difficult to fit it snugly into one category. It's an action RPG, it's grand strategy, it's a simulation, it's open world. This game is a whole bunch of things that melt so perfectly together, and it is unlike any other game I've ever played. For anyone who is even the slightest bit interested in medieval warfare, this is the game you never knew you wanted.

You start out by answering some simple questions about the life your character has lived thus far, and critiquing the way your heroine (or hero) looks. You are thrown into the large continent of Calradia which is split into six unique factions that are constantly at war with each other. The world map is familiar to those of us who enjoy grand strategy games; you can view the land and the castles/towns/villages/hideouts etc. that exist on it at any one time, while your character and her horse moves along it like a pawn on a gameboard. The colors of the names tell you which faction currently owns and controls each piece of land. What you begin to do from here is ultimately up to you. You can try doing favors for lords and kings to win their favor and ultimately work for them, whilst building up a small army of ragtag soldiers that you recruit and hire from various places, or you can be bold and try almost immediately to begin taking over land yourself (which I wouldn't recommend for the first dozen or so hours into the game).

Battles in this game are nothing short of amazing. Both warring sides start out on opposite ends of the map (I've never seen the same battlefield twice, by the way, so I believe they are randomized based on the terrain type you are currently traversing). You can issue commands to your army, and this is fun to mess around with. For example, you can tell your archers to stand their ground and your cavalry to charge the enemy, while giving a different order to infantry. It's all up to you. By default, all units will charge, and for the most part, this is sufficient. You will then meet your enemy in the battlefield, where cavalry can run over infantry, archers can shoot riders off of horses, and you can kill horses while their riders are still living, making them fall face first into the ground before swarming them. Basically, if you've ever seen two opposing sides charge in a movie and have felt that intensity and awe, you can actually play as one of those people involved in Mount & Blade, and each and every time it's amazing. This game is fantastic for nerds like me who love anything medieval; not only are there full out battles like this, but you eventually (and your army) get strong enough to take over castles, towns, etc., and you get to be one of the units that is a part of this, each and every single time.

The goal regardless seems to be to take over the entire map of land, whether through an existing faction or through your own, which you may create once you have a strong enough army to begin taking over land by force. Lords will double cross you, downright insult you, and even beg their respective kings for the rights to a castle you may have taken over yourself, and depending on the circumstance, you may or may not be jipped out of a piece of land you worked hard for. You can then, however, decide to accept that or give a one fingered salute to your king before renouncing your allegiance and going your own way. It is entirely up to you.

I would highly, highly recommend you play as a woman character, even if you are not a woman in real life. The game is fantastic at reflecting the negative attitudes toward women at the time, and those mentalities can highly influence you during the game. For example, I created a woman character and named her after myself, much like I did for the first Mount and Blade. I set about leveling up my character and recruiting soldiers, and picked up a mercenary contract for a faction. After taking over three castles single-handedly for the faction's king, I spoke to the king, introduced myself, and asked to be promoted to being his vassal. He told me outright that he didn't care what I had accomplished. Because I was a woman, I could not be his vassal, and I couldn't own land. I asked him what would happen if I took an enemy castle by force, and he replied that he would think about" letting me keep it. This sexist attitude (although very realistic for the time) got me so fired up that I promptly cancelled my contract with the king and began taking over his land by force. After about 40 hours of in-game time
date: he was exiled from the land
hoursPlayed: and all of his land belonged to a new faction appropriately named "Rosie's Kingdom of Awesome." About 40 hours after that
voteText: I was Queen of Calradia. But it all started because of my motivation to overthrow an arrogant and sexist king as the woman he insulted

reviewText: Probably one of the most addicting games of it's genre. The combat system is amazing and unique. The skill base system makes it a very rewarding game. The singleplayer features countless hours of gameplay which cease to bore you. You control the game with multiple choice actions and such. The multiplayer is unique in it's own way as it features numerous gamemodes which you can play with your friends. You can join a server on the official server list or you can host a private server for just your friends. There are no fixed goals to this game. You can set them for yourself. Stay as a mercenary or become a king. You can work this game at your own pace. Once you get bored of the game, try out the countless mods and DLC. If you open yourself up to the learning curve, you will find a game unlike anything else around.

reviewText:
A remake of the original Mount & Blade. Probably the only medieval RPG/War Simulation/Sandbox/Strategy game that I know of. Wake up in the land of Calradia - Where six factions fight for the land. Find yourself in the lowest caste of the Dark Ages. A deserter, a slave or bandit - Or be a noble lady daringly looking for adventure. Raise an army and pledge alliance under one of the existing factions - Or be bold enough to rebel and create your own faction.

What makes this game unique is that you can be Anyone in Calradia. If you feel like protecting your king at all costs - then that's your game. Want to be a savage bandit and burn every village you see - your game. Want to play as a useless merchant with a merc army fighting for you - your game. Maybe as the strategist where you sit back with a few of your men on your battlefield, while you carefully execute your plan of attack. I have tried all different roles, and they all give me this excitement for every battle.

You can choose to become the ultimate killing machine by not training an army but only yourself. You will gain most experience for each kill rather than every battle won, so while you are extremely strong and undefeated - your army might be really weak and untrained. While being the strategist, you might have very well knowledge in leading your troops, but you do little damage yourself. So there are a lot of different ways to approach this game, and you will sink countless of hours into it.

In the early stages of the game, you pretty much just hunt down bandits for villages and vassals. Slowly you will recruit a small army and gain som renown. Mid-game is all about getting a good relation with one/several of the Kings - to secure your role. When strong enough you can choose to enter late-game by leading your faction to domination, or break out to become the ruler of your own faction: Acquire land and start getting vassals under yourself. All this plus a lot of side quests, such as getting married or starting a merchant business gives countless amounts of replayablitiy.

The multiplayer scene is Very interesting as well, with huge battles up to 250 players (!). It only consists of battlefields though, and not the coveted co-op/versus mode on the single-player map. Imagine you and your friends fighting over Calradia's many castles and towns. Something I really wish for in Mount & Blade 2.

This game is for you if you like Medieval/Sandbox/Strategy/Simuator games, and wants to spend 100+ hours on building your army and faction.

reviewText: Mount & Blade: Warband is the sequel to Mount & Blade, a medieval-styled RPG where you create your own specific character, customize it's backstory the way you like, and play in an open world however you choose. There is no real story to the game other than the story you decide to create, which makes this a different type of RPG than we've come to expect. I have not had the chance to play the original; However, the graphics for Warband look a bit dated and the slightly wider than normal field of view seemed to give me a little bit of a headache. The open world aspect of the game makes up for the visual limitations, though the tutorial I thought was a little awkward.\n\nMount & Blade: Warband also has a multiplayer mode and comes with the ability to be modded. There are a couple of Downloadable content packs, Napoleonic Wars which is for multiplayer, and Viking Conquest which is for single player. There is also a newly released edition of the game called the Reforged Edition, which is supposed to be an improvement to the game, though I have not had the chance to look into this further. In all, I think Mount & Blade: Warband was fun for an RPG, but I would have liked some kind of story. It has some drawbacks visually, but makes up for it with versatility and player customization. If you like Open world RPG's and want to create your own story, this is a game you should try out.

reviewText: The laziest cat in America swaps places with the richest feline in England in director Tim Hill's lasagna-laden sequel to the 2004 theatrical hit Garfield. Jon Arbuckle (Breckin Meyer) is on his way to London to propose to his veterinarian girlfriend, Liz Wilson (Jennifer Love Hewitt), and his unflappable cat, Garfield, is determined to be there when Jon pops the big question. Of course, Garfield wouldn't go anywhere without his old pal Odie, and soon after arriving in the land of Big Ben, the clueless tomcat inadvertently changes places with royal look-a-like Prince. It seems that Prince's owner, Lady Eleanor, has recently passed away, leaving the care of her sprawling estate Castle Carlyle in the capable paws of her devoted kitty companion. The trouble is, Prince has decided it's due time for a vacation, and with Garfield in charge there's no telling what kind of trouble will befall Castle Carlyle. Despite having a devoted butler named Smithee (Ian Abercrombie) to cater to his every whim and a whole host of fun-loving critters with whom to pass the lazy days spent lounging in the sun, this crowned head begins to feel the sting of deceit as the envious Lord Dargis (Billy Connolly) hatches a dastardly plan to do away with the whiskered heir and claim Castle Carlyle all to himself. Meanwhile, as Garfield attempts to hold his ground against his greedy would-be nemesis, the fun-loving Prince is living it up with Jon and Odie by taking a trip to some of London's most popular pubs. ~ Jason Buchanan, Rovi

reviewText:
There are 2 parts to this game: singleplay and muliplayer. They're both completely different.

Singleplayer is more a worldmap strategy RPG. Once you get into battle it's a 3rd-person midieval battle simulator. There are many mods for singleplayer to fit it to a theme or playstyle of your liking. It is a very diverse and interesting game, with almost countless hours of gameplay.

Muliplayer is also amazing. The combat is perfect. Simply swing or block -up left down right-. There are more advanced features to sword combat that make this more of a skill-based game. Ontop of that there are archers and cavalry. The game is balanced and broken in all the right ways. It is total caos in the battlefield, bringing many a good laugh along with it. There are also many multiplayer mods that make for an interesting expereince.

Overalll, this is one of the best games I have EVER played. Mostly becuase it gives the user a diverse experience through the differing modes and mods. There are so many things to do in this game, you just have to try it for yourself.

reviewText: A while back, I was on Gaikai.com playing a short demo of Assassins Creed: Revelations when I saw a demo for a game called Mount and Blade: Warband. Intrigued, I booted up the demo and started playing. I must have played the demo hundreds of times. It was some of the best fun I had ever had with a game. It may be listed as an RTS, but it is so much more than that. I can think of no other game that drops you right in the middle of the action, forcing you to charge in at the front lines rather than float above the clouds and click soldiers around a tiled map. Is it perfect? Certainly not. But no game is perfect. And any sort of problems you may run into can be solved by waiting. They usually clear up very soon. The quests, the characters, the world, and the gameplay in general all have a certain wonder about them, making it a must-play for all fans of medieval and strategy alike.\n\nFinal Score: 10/10 - A wonderful game that can suck you in and cause you to lose countless hours. Truly a must-play game.

reviewText:
Mount and Blade Warband is the standalone expansion to Mount and Blade, or the sequel, I guess that's really just a matter of perspective. Warband is basically the same game as Mount & Blade with a lot of new features, fixes and content added, most of which was taken straight out of the various mods available for the original. The only original thing Warband adds, and perhaps the most important thing, is the multi-player.

One of the first and most sweeping additions is an enhanced skirmish mode as well as a full fledged multi-player. In you were pretty much limited to some preset skirmish maps which have now been replaced with a number of maps, modes and the ability to customize both your army, your enemies and your own character which makes for a much more enjoyable experience.

Another new addition that gives you something to do outside is the addition of multi-player. Although Mount & Blade was never designed for with multi-player in mind it is something the fans have been asking for since the beginning and much to everyone's surprise, it works wonderfully. The multi-player is reminiscent of a regular big battle in the main game with the notable difference that every enemy and ally is controlled by a real human, something that ups the difficulty dramatically and opens up a number of different tactics to use.

The single-player additions are all very nice but they also all things that were already available through the many mods available and as such they are not really that big of an improvement except for those players that don't use mods. There is a big graphical overhaul that helps shake off a little of a beta product feel the original game had, the animations and texture quality is still pretty low though. You also get a new faction based on Islamic medieval which is pretty nice but unfortunately it doesn't really fill in any of the unit niches that the other factions do. Politics have been greatly improved by including the ability to create your own faction which was only available through mods before.

All in all Warband is a great improvement over the original Mount & Blade although I wouldn't exactly go as far as to call it a true sequel, it's a stand-alone expansion. And although all the improvements make for a much stronger base game almost all of these improvements were already available through mods with the exception of the multi-player which makes the game feel somewhat lacking for someone that has played the mods. That being said, the multi-player is an awesome addition and loads of fun and in particular if you get the Napoleonic DLC you will find some of the most strategic hack and slash gameplay anywhere.

reviewText:
This game is amazing, the single player campaign on it is pretty good, when I did the story mode I was a noob so I was forever captured which was rather annoying. I did manage to progress though and now I have conquered all of Calradia and have started a new game as a woman.

The multiplayer for Native is also very good as well, you get more money for killing people so evidently, those who are skilled will have the best armour and weaponry, this does lead to some unfair fights but it does provide a good challenge for those who wish to improve. Apart from that I can't think of anything wrong with Native mode.

Then there is that mountain of mods.

I have played a few of mods, Iron Europe, Nord invasion, AZW Reloaded, Blood in the West and Napoleonic Wars. The Napoleonic Wars mod is awesome. The multiplayer on it is the best and the community is great too. It is on this mod where you tend to get most of the regiments and all that, they do massive events which can have a max of 200 people in so of course, lag is inevitable. It's in these regiments were the majority of people rack up their gaming hours and who's to blame, they are genuinely fun things to partake in.

I have not played much of the Iron Europe mod but that is mainly because not many go on it. If more played it then I would definately spend more time on it too. However, the way how people tend to fight on it is mostly through shooting, and if you get too close then people have the tendency to retreat and gun you down or throw a grenade at you. There is definately some good potential for this mod though.

The Nord Invasion mod is basically you and a maximum of 15 other people against waves of Nords. In order to progress you must make an account on the Nord Invasion website, through this you buy the equipment that you want and even level up. It is rather addicting and the last wave is quite the challenge. The way to win in this mod is through teamwork and also having good equipment. It is not hard to get good equipment as a lot can be picked up in the map for you to use, as well as this, you don't even need to kill Nords to acquire xp, you get it simply for near those who get kills.

The AZW Reloaded mod, which is a Zulu Wars mod, for me needs a fair bit of patching because, for me it I had great big grey bars coming from the bots which obscured half the screen, however, the mod I believe has plenty of potential once it's fixed. The mod allows you to play as either the Zulus or the British and the maps will be historically based, such as Rorkes Drift etc. In terms of activity there are not many players and even less server.

The Blood in the West mod is Lord of the Rings based. IT's focused primarily on the single play and the map is of Middle Earth. At the moment it only has the major factions, such as Rohan, Mordor, Gondor, Elves and Dwarves. I think though that over time more will be added. I have been unable to play it much due to the fact that it keeps crashing but from what I have been able to play, it does look really good. The background music is all from the LOTR soundtracks and it even has the main characters and beasts, such as the Fell Beast and the Troll. I have not tried the multiplayer so I shall not talk about that but I would highly recommend this mod provided that you can play it.

10/10

reviewText:
I fought my way up the ranks. People chose to follow me. I sent men in to fight by my side and sometimes we won, others we lost. I've seen my fair share of blood and chaos. Of death and destruction. Villages burned in the distance, people dragged from their homes, women ♥♥♥♥♥, children murdered. I saw what men were really capable of on those darkest of days where there was no law or order. Just us and them out in the grassy knoll where no one is safe, and anyone can die at any moment.

I made a choice that day, as many of us do, to do what I felt was right.

and it haunts me to this day.

reviewText:
Although Mount & Blade: Warband takes place in a fantasy setting, it is worthy of being called the best medieval warfare simulator on the market. Warband is an entire genre of its own, merging a sandbox RPG world with feudal politics and a complex simulation of combat. Miles ahead of its competitors, Warband's single-player mode offers a near infinite amount of replayability, and its online mode further emphasizes the brilliance of its combat system.

Easily a 10/10, Warband is further supplemented by a host of breathtaking mods which can be found at the Taleworlds forums and Mod DB. My personal favourites are:

1. 1257 AD: an incredible historic overhaul which brings Warband into medieval Europe, as well as introduces a host of other improvements
2. The Deluge: a historical overhaul that brings Warband into 17th century Eastern Europe, inspired by Henryk Sienkiewicz's novel.
3. A Clash of Kings: Fantastic overhaul that brings Warband into the world of Game of Thrones.
4. Iron Europe: a multiplayer overhaul that brings players right into the First World War!

reviewText:
Highly authentic medieval combat.  The most unique gaming experience I've had in a
long time.  In 8 hours of this Action Adventure game I've trained in weapons, archery and horseback, fought in tournaments, searched for volunteers for my mercenary band, fought bandits and deserters, tracked down criminals, ran errands for lords, delivered ransoms, ransomed/sold prisoners into slavery, traded goods between villages, trained villagers to fend for themselves, delivered aid to said villagers, drove cattle, wrangled cattle, lost in battle and was captured several times.

I'm still a lowly mercenary and have yet to even become a vessel, let alone fight in a war or earn a fief and who knows what else.

This is NOT some text based RPG.
I can't put it down and highly recommend this game to anyone who loves this era.

reviewText:
He stood and observed the audience with tired, almost lifeless eyes. Cleaning his throat, he started his speech:
- Today it is my third day without Mount & Blade: Warband. 70... 78 hours to be precise...


The audience was shocked. The silence rested in the room for few seconds until someone on the left started a timid clap, leading the rest of the room. Everybody was marvelled - how could someone start playing Mount & Blade: Warband and quit for 78 hours?! That was almost beyond comprehension.

He said, with a half smile on his lips but the fatigue in his soul still clear in his eyes:
- Thank you, thank you. It is hard, but I am struggling. After 3 years and a half, I believe... my brothers, I believe I will never look back.

A young boy could be seen whispering in his neighbour's ears
- Do you think I'll get there some day? Do you think I will manage to stop playing one day?
to which the other boy replied
- We can only dream... he has shown us that there is hope...

The audience went nuts and clapping and shouting of joy; that's what they have been waiting for, for a hope, that that young man had just unannouncedly brought to them all. With a gesture of his hands, he urged the audience to quiet down, his life slowly coming back to him at that moment, the smile brightening up in his face, and then he said
- My brothers! I am free! I shall never play Mount & Blade: Warband anylonger. I have prevailed.

Filled the hearts with that hope that day, that young man has never returned the MBW Addiction Centre. Two days from that he would find out that he was very wrong - he answered the call to save Calradia, and returned to Mount & Blade: Warband, and was once again showered by the glory of the battlefield.
- One does not simple stop playing Mount & Blade: Warband
he thought. Yet this time he was almost right for that was almost the truth. None, none of them could possibly rid their lives from Mount & Blade: Warband ever again, until that day in which a greater glory would await.

Until Mount & Blade: Bannerlord, their souls was bound - and they knew it.

reviewText:
This game is a masterpiece in many ways.

First of all, the game has such a special feeling in it that many other games fail to provide. You really feel like a glorious warrior that is running down at the battlefield, charging towards the enemy.

In this game, you can lead your own army. Not in the Total War style, but be down there on the ground fighting as a general. If you die, your unit loses. Simple as that.

Even though this game is old, it still has the amazing feel to it, and it has a very big replayability chance. Eventually, if you get bored of the native Mount & Blade: Warband, I recommend you to go check out Napoleonic Wars, which I have written a seperate review on.

Go on now, young warrior, grab this game and proceed on to the battlefields!

reviewText:
I'd like to call myself a connoisseur on Medieval role-playing games, though there's so many more out there that I've never played, and most likely never will. This would have been one of those games I'd have had a look at in the Steam store and then never considered again, but a fanboy-friend of mine convinced me otherwise, and boy, am I grateful for that.

I usually have a strong dislike for all games that do not feature semi-photo-realism graphics. In fact, I was absolutely abhorred by the lack of a strong character-creation component. I loved Skyrim's and Dragon Age: Origin's character-creation. Hell, I even preferred some MMORPG's character graphics over this game's. I had to force myslef to stop whining and actually try the game. And when I did, I found that the true gem that this game is, doesn't rely on graphics or beautification and landscapes to get you addicted, but rather on the absolutely amazing gameplay.

The game's combat system trumps that of any other game I've ever played, and the game offers you a wide variety of options to reach any end. Also, it recreates a much more realistic, much less sophisticated view on actual medieval feudal society. It also boasts a great warband combat system, as the name suggests. The options and formations take a while to grasp, but in the end, it's a system better than in any other game, as far as I know.

reviewText:
This was my first entry into the Mount & Blade series, instantly becoming a favourite of mine. This is a fairly low-budget, open world RPG in which you create a relatively simple player background, leaving much to be created in your own imagination.

While some may see this as a limitation, it's also a huge advantage for people who want to create their own identity within the game and focus on role-playing. You also choose one of the regions to start in, all of which have their strengths and limitations, for instance Vaegir are great at ranged combat, but not so skilled with two-handed weapons, although this doesn't effect your characters abilities, simply the types of enemies and available weaponry.

Part of what makes this game so great is the fact that you could literally role-play anything you wanted, an honourable knight, a brutal raider, or anything inbetween. You slowly build up your band of warriors and complete quests, you start earning the real money when you join your first military campaign by swearing an oath to a king. You can lead on to amassing an empire of property and riches, conquering the world map and even become a king yourself! (with enough time of course)

The combat system is by far the highlight of the game, with excellent sword-play both on and off horseback. It doesn't over-complicate things while keeping you fully invested in the battles. While archery is fun, I find it to be nothing too special, and if the enemies go heavy on shields, it's really hard to hit anything.

The two DLCs seem to be hit-or-miss however, Napoleonic Wars is only multiplayer, so unless you get really into that it's not worth it. Viking Conquest looks like it could be great, but it's filled with unsolved bugs. [EDIT: Viking Conquest Reforged seems to have resolved many issues, but still, buyers beware.]

There is also an array of excellent workshop items and mods that completley transform the games setting, graphics and even overhaul the entire combat system with the game allowing you to switch between mods the the original game wth a simple drop down menu, giving immense amounts of replayability.

I highly recommend picking up the core game as soon as possible.

reviewText:
What exactly is Mount & Blade? Partly it is a medieval fighting simulator, partly role playing game and partly a strategy game. All of this is present in this huge chunk of buggy code wrapped in mediocre graphics. But that is little too harsh, because this game has something to overcome all of this. Flawless gameplay.

You start by creating your character in not too deep creator. There is couple of background choices which will determine your stats. Stats are the RPG part of the game, you get all the basics like strenght, agility and intelligence, followed by skills that determine your abiliy to hold shields, ride a horse or get better prices from traders. At the very last there are the weapon stats, those are here to tell you how well you will fare with different kind of weapons. You can choose between bows, crossbows, short or long swords, spears and polearms.

After you are done spending your points, you get a piece of the fighting simulator. You get thrown into an one on one fight without any sort of tutorial, this game is expansion after all, so you should already know everything right? Well, in case you did not play the original... Generally you use left mouse button for attacking and right mouse button for defending. That's pretty common right? But that is obviously not everything. By moving the mouse to either of four directions (right, left, up, down) prior to the swing you determine the manner of the attack. To add more fun to this, you can do the same while defending, so basically you have to check your opponent's movement and react fast enough to block. However if you are not up to the challenge you can use automatic blocking, in this case you will only need to time the block and the direction will be automatically chosen by computer. So that's it, quite simple is it not? Other weapons are similar with small differences mostly in possible manners of attacking. Ranged weapons are even more challenging. There is no aim indicator and arrows, bolts or javelins respect the laws of gravity, so it will take a while to get used to it.

Well, that was quite elaborate description of fighting system, I hope I did not bore you. This leaves us with strategy part of the game. So yeah, after you finish your first fight you get your first quest (yep, another sign of rpg) and end up on a huge map, not too unlike Total War world maps, but way uglier, and move your character around. Everything is in real time, but since the time stops everytime your character stops, in principle the game is more similar to turnbased games. So there you are on a huge map, large groups of enemies moving around you. You may try to challenge one of the groups yourself and find out, that you are no hero, just another warrior who gets butchered when facing more than 2 or 3 enemies at once. At this point you get to one of the villages and recruit yourself a bunch of peasants. Soon enough you will find that peasants are more like meat shields and die a lot, but with a piece of luck and good commander (you) they can make it as far as to knighthood. This all sounds more like tactics than strategy right (wink)? Well, to be honest I am not sure how it works in vanilla (unmodded) game, since after original Mount & Blade, in Warband I started with mods right away.

Yes, mods are the greatest thing that could have happened to this game. The basics are great but the game itself needed helluva lot of polishing to become a legend. There are tons of mods ready to be tried and some of them are really robust. I myself am using Floris mod pack (to be find on nexusmods.com) which combines many different mods improving graphics and gameplay alike. And the strategy part I was talking about is part of this mod, since in here, before the fight starts you get to strain your mind by choosing how will your units behave during the battle. You had probably already guessed that I think that Mount & Blade: Warband is a good game, well you are right, but with mods, it becomes a GREAT game.

reviewText: A charming, rustic, free roaming rpg that combines elements of strategy, politics and 3rd person rpg combat. It's a sandbox game where you will have to grind quite bit, but it doesn't really have a clear goal and every type of activity is permitted. On its own the game isn't that great, since it somewhat restricts your freedom of actions, but make sure to install couple of mods (famous floris for example) and it will bloom.\nAlso, there's a fairly popular multiplayer in place, but I'm not sure how good it is. Overall, I would recommend this game if you like to roam around fighting random battles, carving a piece of world for yourself by capturing cities/fortresses and you're willing to sink a hundred or so hours doing it.

reviewText:
Great game, I'm completely hooked to this game and let me tell you why you should buy this:
-There is no storyline but lots of freedom, so the player can create his own story. May it be a band of mercenaries or being a big part of an existing kingdom and attacking all these motherfuppers who dare to claim the throne.
-Good mod support. It's fairly easy to mod your game yourself with a bit of reading, and there are many existing mods that add so much to the game.
-Serious multiplayer. It's comparable to Chivalry: Medieval Warfare, but with a more mature fanbase and more serious people. Also, regiments.
-Developers of this game are having a nice amount of contact with players through the forums and the beta tests.
-A great amount of different troops, approaches and tactics. There is something for everyone, charging in with heavy cavalry or laying back with a pack of archers and crossbowmen. In battle, you can give orders to either Everyone, Infantry, Archery, Cavalry or a user-set group of units, giving you the maximum amount of control during battles and using your troops as efficiently as possible.

Once you start a new game, you might want to build up a force as soon as possible because the bandits will ♥♥♥♥ you up if you don't have a big enough force of men.

reviewText:
Well, what Can I say? Not much really, This game really is impressive. After playing on it for hundreds of hours I can truly say this is a Go-To game, I'm not doing anything, Mount and Blade, easy as that. While it has its bugs and in some areas shows clear signs of underdevelopement (<not even a word) it truly is something of an innovation so to speak, Napoleonic Wars for instance is my main reason for this, I mean who has seen any other FPS set in the Napoleonic Wars era? While the graphics could be considered lacking the gameplay is the reason this game is what it is. Shooting, Melee, Artillery, Musicians. Whatever you want from a Napoleonic era war game, It's there. And now I've realised how much I've talked about this game, when I said there isn't much to talk about. In summary. GREAT GAME, If you can ignore the sometimes to frequent bugs and lag which may lead you to die rather abrubtly.



Also, If you play musician and expect mercy, It ain't gonna happen, If you surrender and you expect mercy, it definitely isn't gonna happen.



Melee can be an absolute B**ch sometimes, don't expect to be any good at first.





BIG TIP: DO NOT JOIN THE 15TH ROF, I got banned for having a life. And getting a job.
In fact I will probably be labelled a 'troll' or 'bush pirate' for pointing out a major issue with this game: THE 15TH REGIMENT OF FOOT NEEDS TO BE PATCHED!

reviewText:
Over a thousand hours poured into the game. I decided its time to say exactly why I've spent this much time playing it.

Warband is a game that attempts many things, being a medieval combat sim, a sandbox, a RPG of sorts, and much more. It has many strengths and a few weaknesses.

PROS:
Strong modding community. There are hundreds of innovative and fun mods that reall revamp the game and add new life to it each time you play.(To name a few, Blood and Steel, A New Dawn, cRPG(this ones MP), Perisnio, and thats not even scratching the surface).

Infinite replay value. Each time you replay you can do something completly new and different

The melee combat is somewhat difficult to learn but once you do its innovative and always fun

Multiplayer in just native is somewhat boring, but there are a few mods that add tons of new stuff. Like Persistent World which makes it sort of like an MMO, cRPG which adds consistent characters, and I'm sure there are a few more.

CONS:
Lack of things to do in Native gets a bit boring.

Ranged in base game and most mods is very overpowered.

reviewText:
So you've played every popular multiplayer FPS under the sun and are looking to ditch the guns in favor of something a bit more personal.   Well, this is the game for you.  Pick up your favorite melee weapon and get up close to your enemy so you can see that look on his face just before you stab him in it.

A good analogy for how multiplayer works in this game is Counterstrike without the guns.  You start each round with a set amount of cash and some free equipment and then pick and choose between your nation's weapons/armor of choice and then take to the field and try not to get yourself killed while hopefully taking a few of the enemy out along the way.  In addition to excellent infantry related combat, archery, cavalry and horse-archery are all represented as well if being a ground pounder isn't your thing.

Also, although the multiplayer is a real blast, the game also features a great sandbox-style (think Sid Meier's Pirates) singleplayer game where you start off as a lowly peasant and work your way up to leading huge armies and ruling your own kingdom. There is no linear storyline or hand-holding you here, the game is what you make of it. If you've ever wondered what it would be like to play a general from the Total War series from a first or third person perspective, this game will somewhat give you that experience. If you have a high-end gaming rig, you can set the battle size up to like 500+ units on screen at once (with a small third-party tool).

The game's graphics aren't on the cutting edge of current technology, but they allow for huge battles.  Where the game really shines is in its combat.  It's one of the few games I've ever seen where you control your attack/block directions.  Watching 2 pro's go at it is akin to watching a well coreographed movie fight.

I cannot recommend this game enough. You just don't see GOOD medieval combat anywhere really. This isn't some button hammering console combat game. Check out the demo!

reviewText:
Mount and Blade Warband is what every game should aspire to be.

Sometimes you find a game that resonates with you, and goes beyond the game itself into a kind of meta-game and opens doors for you to do your own thing. Traditionally this is called sandbox - the problem with most sandbox titles is there is literally no direction. Warband avoid that weakness while still allowing you to feel the freedom and be inspired by it.

The gameplay can be either simplified or incredibly unrelenting. The difficulty settings alone can make two games entirely different in every way. I enjoy playing an unstoppable warlord, a beast of death and carnage, a visage of loss and trauma to all who stand against me (I play on the easiest settings, which makes my troops take far less damage and inflict greater damage to enemy units). Or you can boost the difficulty and turn it into a fairly realistic army game, where your troops are just as easy to kill as the enemy.

Many games will give you a sense of power, but few capture the feeling of charging down a hillside with 50 armored knights at your back and crashing into the enemy formation.

For the price, you will not find a better game on planet earth. And this doesn't even begin to touch on all the mods created by a hugely inventive and dedicated community. Seriously, buy the game. Give it ten hours to learn the ropes and you will love it. If you don't, I will eat a shoe.

(I will not eat a shoe)

reviewText:
This game is amazingFirst, I bought Warband. I started a new singleplayer game, named myself after a great emperor, made an army, attacked a village, got defeated, robbed, sold as a slave, and then left on the roads with no money and a horse.
I decided then to try multiplayer. I joined a siege server, got teamkilled and kicked for getting revenge. I joined, then, an arena server also known as deathmatch, got backstabbed in the exact same moment I spawned, then got killed by cavalry and campers.
I bought the Napoleonic Wars DLC thinking it's better. It is epic. I joined a Team Deathmatch and Siege server, but now, I kicked a troller of a cliff, got teamkilled by a cannonball, and started arguing with admin. Then I joined the deathmatch server, I spawned, got shot with a musket, I respawned, killed a nude guy who than respawned as cavalry and killed me. Then I disconnected because the server crashed.
It's not like I'm playing the game everyday or something (I am), but I just can't get bored of trolling guys and making false teams in deathmatch. Did I mention you can shoot your teammates with the cannon?
This game is fabulous. 11/10 would buy again.

reviewText:
Mount & Blade Warband is a significant improval over the original game, it uses the motion capture technology, which makes all the character's movements a lot much smoother and life-like.
But the game really shines when it comes to gameplay. This medieval RPG, mixes Total War scale battles with action, it's a sandbox game, which means you can play litterly to no end. But the amount of detail put into this game is very impressive and makes it for a very good atmosphere. In general, it's a great game if you like the medieval era, the clash of swords and the strings of bows and especially a good challenge, for the combat system offers challenge equal to none in the video game industry.

There is a free demo on Steam that you can try, to get a feel for the game.
It is indeed a unique product.

reviewText:
Mount & Blade : Warband is the best Multiplayer game I have ever played so far. The selection of mods you are able to play is huge, the community great, it keeps you playing for thousands of hours. I myself only play the awesome (most awesome) mod c-RPG which already kept me playing for 3 and a half to 4 years. The thing I, and most of the community, love most at this game is the fighting system which requires a lot of skill if you want to be good and the community which keeps playing this game actively since almost release. So I give this game a huge 11/10 because it is the only game keeping me playing for over 4 years (actively). The fighting system is quite hard at the beginning but if you have someone who's better than you, ask him for training and you'll be a good warrior in no time. And for the beginners:
Do not be frustrated if you cant reach scores like 20:3 in your first hundrer hours. It takes a lot of time you spend practicing every class to be as good as most veteran players are nowadays.
So if you buy this game, play Native or even the Singleplayer at first, then move on to mods like Mercenaries or c-RPG or play the DLC Napoleonic: Wars which costs 10 Euros.
If you want to know more about c-RPG, check out the guide I've written!

Ahhh adventure... what is better then living the good life of a nobody and raise to power. Of course you may have to cut a few heads on the way... escape looter, raiders,  forest bandit seek refuge in one of the regional kingdom, raise a army and destroy everyone else kingdoms. Not to speak of driving cattle horde. Marry a noble girl without his father consent. In clear your typical middle ages life.

Mount & blade Warband offer all that and more.

Also if you are competitive note that the game containt a multiplayer mode that is probably the most challenging PvP game out there, forget about the CoD and WoW of this world. To be good at this, you literaly need to stay in shape and train yourself at sword fighting to survive huge battle.

reviewText:
Over a thousand hours poured into the game. I decided its time to say exactly why I've spent this much time playing it.

Warband is a game that attempts many things, being a medieval combat sim, a sandbox, a RPG of sorts, and much more. It has many strengths and a few weaknesses.

PROS:
Strong modding community. There are hundreds of innovative and fun mods that reall revamp the game and add new life to it each time you play.(To name a few, Blood and Steel, A New Dawn, cRPG(this ones MP), Perisnio, and thats not even scratching the surface).

Infinite replay value. Each time you replay you can do something completly new and different

The melee combat is somewhat difficult to learn but once you do its innovative and always fun

Multiplayer in just native is somewhat boring, but there are a few mods that add tons of new stuff. Like Persistent World which makes it sort of like an MMO, cRPG which adds consistent characters, and I'm sure there are a few more.

CONS:
Lack of things to do in Native gets a bit boring.

Ranged in base game and most mods is very overpowered.
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Mount & Blade Warband is a significant improval over the original game, it uses the motion capture technology, which makes all the character's movements a lot much smoother and life-like.
But the game really shines when it comes to gameplay. This medieval RPG, mixes Total War scale battles with action, it's a sandbox game, which means you can play litterly to no end. But the amount of detail put into this game is very impressive and makes it for a very good atmosphere. In general, it's a great game if you like the medieval era, the clash of swords and the strings of bows and especially a good challenge, for the combat system offers challenge equal to none in the video game industry.

There is a free demo on Steam that you can try, to get a feel for the game.
It is indeed a unique product.

reviewText:
Mount & Blade : Warband is the best Multiplayer game I have ever played so far. The selection of mods you are able to play is huge, the community great, it keeps you playing for thousands of hours. I myself only play the awesome (most awesome) mod c-RPG which already kept me playing for 3 and a half to 4 years. The thing I, and most of the community, love most at this game is the fighting system which requires a lot of skill if you want to be good and the community which keeps playing this game actively since almost release. So I give this game a huge 11/10 because it is the only game keeping me playing for over 4 years (actively). The fighting system is quite hard at the beginning but if you have someone who's better than you, ask him for training and you'll be a good warrior in no time. And for the beginners:
Do not be frustrated if you cant reach scores like 20:3 in your first hundrer hours. It takes a lot of time you spend practicing every class to be as good as most veteran players are nowadays.
So if you buy this game, play Native or even the Singleplayer at first, then move on to mods like Mercenaries or c-RPG or play the DLC Napoleonic: Wars which costs 10 Euros.
If you want to know more about c-RPG, check out the guide I've written!

reviewText:
Well, what Can I say? Not much really, This game really is impressive. After playing on it for hundreds of hours I can truly say this is a Go-To game, I'm not doing anything, Mount and Blade, easy as that. While it has its bugs and in some areas shows clear signs of underdevelopement (<not even a word) it truly is something of an innovation so to speak, Napoleonic Wars for instance is my main reason for this, I mean who has seen any other FPS set in the Napoleonic Wars era? While the graphics could be considered lacking the gameplay is the reason this game is what it is. Shooting, Melee, Artillery, Musicians. Whatever you want from a Napoleonic era war game, It's there. And now I've realised how much I've talked about this game, when I said there isn't much to talk about. In summary. GREAT GAME, If you can ignore the sometimes to frequent bugs and lag which may lead you to die rather abrubtly.



Also, If you play musician and expect mercy, It ain't gonna happen, If you surrender and you expect mercy, it definitely isn't gonna happen.



Melee can be an absolute B**ch sometimes, don't expect to be any good at first.





BIG TIP: DO NOT JOIN THE 15TH ROF, I got banned for having a life. And getting a job.
In fact I will probably be labelled a 'troll' or 'bush pirate' for pointing out a major issue with this game: THE 15TH REGIMENT OF FOOT NEEDS TO BE PATCHED!

reviewText:
A brilliant RPG
Just picture a vast continent filled with 22 cities and 48 castles each with several villages split amongst 6 factions constantly at war fighting for control and it's all your playground.

Do you play the noble knight, swearing homage to a lord and defending the poor peasants? How about a bandit pillaging the villages and raiding trade caravans to line your pockets? Or maybe you have aspirations for the throne. Build an army and carve out an empire under your own banner. These are but a few options that you can take.

There are a sizeable amount of skill options that allow the creation of many types of characters from the heavily armoured knight to the swift horse archer.

The game has a rather steep learning curve however practice and patience will give results.
The difficulty is easily customised to your preference from the options menu.
The graphics are dated by today's standards and there are still some bugs.

The multiplayer is still active at the time of writing with many dedicated players.
It offers multiple game modes / Deathmatch(free for all) / Team Deathmatch / Siege (teams attack and defend castles) / Capture the Flag / Battle (no respawns).

The community is a mixed bunch, with about an equal split between friendly and ill mannered players.

There is a vast active modding community that offers players the ability to change the settings and mechanics of the game. Genkokujo(Sengoku jidai era of Japan), A Clash of Kings(Game of Thrones) Anno Domini(13th Century Europe), Just to name a few.

PROS
~Vast Customisation
~Re-playability
~Modding
~Skill based Gameplay

CONS
~Learning Curve
~Hit and Miss Community
~Dated Graphics

reviewText:
note* Its going to be hard to explain all of my feelings for this game as it is one of the best games to ever exist on this earth
The Price
I got this on sale but I tell you that this game is worth every penny full price
Premise
Mount and Blade Warband is a sandbox RPG thta takes place in the medival eras of as fantasy land called Calradia. You create a character that can have many backrounds for RPing. When you start a bandit attacks you and the only little bit of story is started to help guide you. I won't say anything on that because this game is best experienced not knowing the setup/ mechanics.

Combat
This games combat is extremely skill based. Each slash with the sword is directional for attacking and blocking. Bows and Arrows are not easy to use and horseback slaying is  satisfying If you have been looking for a game with ealistic medival combat then by god you have found the game for you.

Factions
I am not going to say much becuase each faction is cool and feels like a working breathing organism and only after playing 100 hours I have only scratched their surface. By the time you have picked one you will become fiercly loyal to their cause/conquests. You will argue over with your friends who is the best as each has its own pros cons.

Diplomacy
Diplomacy can be conducted by anyone and usually requires knowledge of each npc's likes and needs. This is how you rise through the ranks in factions but in my opinion can only consist of doing a bunch of varied fetch quests. There are mods like Diplomacy that you can find on the workshop that greatly enhance the experince. All these come toghether and make it feel like your character is just another part in a breathing dynamic world. That is why this game succeds and some rpgs dont because by god its addicting.
Mods
They are god, really good. I suggest try the ones on Workshop and then venture off into Moddbs hardcore/ original mods.
Summary
Buy it, stop reading, buy it. It has first person shooting is has thridperson it has everything.  Now go venture off into Calradia.

reviewText: I say this often, this game is the Stealer of Souls and my Life. I basically have sunk over a hundred hours into it, and I still can get back into it. About 60 of those hours was focused on the Native, but a single mod called Anno Domini really makes it so much better. It became a game that was all around Europe, and for it's time it is an amazing game. I have to stress FOR IT'S TIME however. It has multiple glitches and does not look nearly as well as most games that are similar, but if you are a gamer that can overlook that you will love the game. It can get boring at first, it takes time to get into the game, but give it a bit of a chance, and with a bit of imagination you can really enjoy the game to a wonderful point. You literally go from a common mercenary to a King/Queen. And I must say, being a Queen is rather awesome. Just the feel of people thinking you are in the wrong spot, conquoring the ♥♥♥♥ out of them and then becoming well respected is quite good. Ladies, if you want to beat up men, play this. But I have to give it a 9/10, only point missing is that it hasn't come with a sequal, which I hear they are making, and I pray that it will be just as good, if not better :D.

reviewText: I say this often, this game is the Stealer of Souls and my Life. I basically have sunk over a hundred hours into it, and I still can get back into it. About 60 of those hours was focused on the Native, but a single mod called Anno Domini really makes it so much better. It became a game that was all around Europe, and for it's time it is an amazing game. I have to stress FOR IT'S TIME however. It has multiple glitches and does not look nearly as well as most games that are similar, but if you are a gamer that can overlook that you will love the game. It can get boring at first, it takes time to get into the game, but give it a bit of a chance, and with a bit of imagination you can really enjoy the game to a wonderful point. You literally go from a common mercenary to a King/Queen. And I must say, being a Queen is rather awesome. Just the feel of people thinking you are in the wrong spot, conquoring the ♥♥♥♥ out of them and then becoming well respected is quite good. Ladies, if you want to beat up men, play this. But I have to give it a 9/10, only point missing is that it hasn't come with a sequal, which I hear they are making, and I pray that it will be just as good, if not better :D.

reviewText:
with this game you can feel how would be to be a ruthless nordic conqueror with his shield and axe ready  to open skulls  of you foes or maybe the next Genghis Khan leading a massive army of mounted warrirors with the khergit or pherhaps  like a teutonic inspired   lord  with his big armor and big horse ready to stomp any on your path with the swadia or you may prefer to feel like the great saladin leading your  army of mamelukes ready to conquer all with the sarranid or you prefer the rustic and heavily armed foot troops of the rhodoks master of the crossbows with their large board shields and spears or maybe the peculiar russian like kingdom of the vaegirs to lead knights with bigs bardiches and heavy armor and with the best foot archers to back you up.

it dosent stop there you can also mix the nations as you desire having the best of every nation or your personal preference or you can be a renegade a make your own nation with your own rules  and taking down other nations to finally be king of  all calardria or maybe you like more to lead a  mercenary band  taking what ever you want and doing jobs when ever you want without rules you are free to make mayhem and getting pay for that .

also you have  military management with troops type  plus a in deep leading in battle field mechanic with commands and you leading your army into the fray plus rpg elements to develop your character just the way you want like a warrior with hand and shield or two handed or master of the bow or crossbow or even a more tactican leader doing the best formations in real time battle and more

the game is too big to fit into a tiny review since you can also have companions with full customization that will grow  as you do and you can make then the way you want also the diplomatic options and business

for the lovers of sandbox and medieval times this game is a must have offers a lot of play time and a fun multiplayer with a  massive community support with mods addons and tutorials

the quantity of mods is massive  you pretty much bought many games in one like if you dont like medieval theme   or you got bored you can have a mod that makes everything western style (my favorite ) with guns and awesome music or a game of thrones mod or even a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥  naruto mod  the quantity and quality of the mods that are still coming out is just stunning

this game is a amazing sandbox  with many options for every type of person  with rpg elements with a deep system of leading troops in battle with commands  it has a amazing multiplayer and a pretty active community with awesome mods

i totally recommend it for the sandbox lovers  and im totally gonna buy the sequel

reviewText:
Hey you who is reading this!

Are you looking for a game where you make your own story? Are you ready to take on a task to claim the world?
Then this is the game for you!

Fact: In this game you make your own character which you use to travel the world of Calradia. During your travels u will have the option to recruit soldiers from villagers, capture castles or even cities! Get married, make friends, enemies and become king or queen! Talk to kings and lords and join a faction of your choice. Join your faction in battle and help them capture land. But remember everything you do will change the way of others!

Open world.

This game gets a (10/10) from me buy it!

reviewText:
This game is the ♥♥♥♥, but I suggest doing some practice mode in the beginning. When I first started this game and saw the practice option, my first thought was it's for unskilled noobs. Well, turns out, i'm an unskilled noob. Or was...
First playthrough:
-Attacked by a bandit? Free exp! Oh wait, how do you attack...
-beaten by 1 bandit
-Saved by a merchant (being beaten means you get knocked out)
-hired by the merchant to wipe out a bandit lair
-*Great Success*
-Leave Town
-See a group of 15 Sea Raiders
-Filthy peasants
-Attack
-Forgot I got beaten by 1 bandit
-Knocked out again
-Taken prisoner, lost almost all of my stuff and get dragged around for 2 weeks
-Escape
-You filthy beggars stole my stuff! Give it back or die!
-Knocked out again (Hey! I killed one of them!)
-Lost everything I had left
-♥♥♥♥ this game I'll never play it again
-Play again tomorrow

So if you wat to learn the rage of being 65d onehitted by a rogue spearman or being attacked by khergits who outman you 7 to 1 and you only have footmen (I almost managed to escape by leaving all my men behind!), or if you want to feel the glory of killing 300 swadian militia with 10 huscarls (only 4 died and 3 knocked out), this is a game for you. Just do the practice ok? It's for your own good.

And btw, men who wear dresses become hermaphrodites.

reviewText:
(Just a small, positive review)

An extremely enjoyable Sandbox RPG, and I am not even talking about the multiplayer. The best thing about it, I will not lie, are the mods & modding community, which are both numerous.

(Made a mod myself and I can tell you that it is a highly time robbing process, so imagine total conversions of the game..) Not much else to say, rather then a recommendation.

If you play this game install for multiplayer: cRPG (great character progression), and for singleplayer: Floris Mod Pack (arguably the best singleplayer mod out there).

The Napoleonic Wars DLC cranks up the enjoyment, which is 18th century combat. It's only multiplayer for now though, but singleplayer mods are in development, for which I cannot wait.

Personal score: 8.5/10

Best regards,
Dukhat

reviewText:
i would rate this a solid 10/10, this game is basicly multiple games in one.  in M&B: warband singleplayer, you can create your own character. sad to say the character creation system isnt all it could be, but still well done for a game like this. you start of as a traveler where u can choose your spawn point and your perks, lets call them perks. you start your game with a pretty well done beginning mission. its realy the only mission you have , the rest is more quest based. once your finished with, well the sky is the limit, you can choose the path or either a robbing outlaw fighting for his own or become a vassel and fight for the honour of your king against other kingdom for the control of Caladria.

now for singleplayer as for multiplayer there is a unlimited amount of mods which makes the game 10x better, ive owned the game for about 3 years and have about 2000 hours on it, and i still enjoy the game.

i would highly recommend this game, its a amazing game with endless options.

reviewText: Truly an amazing find. Despite being an older game with outdated graphics, the gameplay is unparalleled and very, very entertaining. The main selling point however, is the opportunities the game gives you to create your own deep and intricate story. I've only run into one or two glitches in the game, and neither were crippling. I would definitely recommend getting this. However, this isn't to say that the game is perfect. Far from it. Here's a list of things it could improve on:\n\n1: Less prerequisites for marriage. Unless you're Stud McHotmuffin and you succeed your eloping proposal on the first try, there's like, 20 things you gotta do to marry someone. You need their father's approval, which means doing over ten fetch quests for him (or many more if you've previously fought him in battle, which would first require a hefty bribe to get him to even listen to you). Then, you need to pay him gold for some reason (remember kids, women aren't people in medieval games). THEN, have the father remain in the game for the whole process. Why's this an issue? Well, paying him then sets up a waiting period of like, 13-30 turns. If he gets exiled from the continent in that time (which he almost always does, since you need to be a high level to successfully romance anyone, and by that point, only a few factions remain), your marriage is broken forever. You can't leave" the relationship

reviewText: Great combat, graphics ok and extremely addictive, the community losing members and gaining members. The campaign is amazing, allowing you to travel across Calradia (The area you are in) build up armies from peasants to full on men at arms and taking over faction after faction and appointing vassals for each castle which can to aid you in the fight to conquer Calradia. The multiplayer is just as great as the single player, you can either just play by your self or you can improve your experience by joining clans and participating in organised events setting a scene of maybe, 100 vs 100 or 50 vs 50 or maybe a small Clan vs Clan. Great game, would recommend it to anyone that enjoys the medieval themed games and for people that enjoy a challenge at the start and like to learn how the game mechanics work and how to use them at its full potential.

reviewText: You can pretty much do whatever you want in this game. You can start off as a poor noble, and attempt to rise to power and become king. Or you can start off as a merchant and make tons of money buying and reselling your goods. Or you can become a bandit and steal from caravans and the rich and make money to raise your own band of thieves. Whatever you choose to do, Mount and Blade Warband is simply enjoyable to play. Also, there is tons of amazing mods to choose from to enhance the game, completely converting the game into ancient Rome, Japan, or even into the the Colonial period with muskets and all.\n\nThe sheer amount of things to do, and the immense replay value factor makes this game extremely easy to reccomend to all! There is someting for everyone here

reviewText:
What are you: a peasant, an impoverished noble, a sociopath, a man looking for riches, or just huntin' for ♥♥♥♥♥es? Whatever the cause, it doesn't matter now. Because you're broke, ♥♥♥♥♥! You arrive penniless in this new land looking for wenches, glory, booty, blood, or any combination thereof. In case if you're a ♥♥♥♥♥, and you forgot the title of this game already: this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ is Mount & Blade: Warband. This game doesn't run off fancy graphics, or modern physics. It is powered off of your precious time and your sorrow filled tears that are wet on your cheeks.

Want to be a King? Get to work peasant! Want to become a merchant scouring the lands for riches? Get to work peasant! Want to be a bandit, just looting villages, and destroying the wayward dreams of many a common peasant? Arise my Lord with sword at the ready!

What am I saying here you ask? I'm saying it's a game for real men. If your balls are low, and blessed with a fine carpet patch of hair, this is the game for you. If you play in anything but the hardest possible mode in the game, just sit down and grab a bite to eat at a local Weenie Hut Jr, while you tape your ♥♥♥♥ in between your legs. It's obvious that you won't be needing that any time soon.

reviewText: Mount and Blade: Warband is the game that the original Mount and Blade wanted to be when it was released.  More polished, more complete, and in all ways improved, this is the best swording-mans simulator on the market.  The modding community is fantastic, offering new maps, troop trees, fief management options, etc.  The only remaining glaring weakness is companion management - in the game, your companions will not automatically equip themselves with improved gear (though many mods add this as a feature) and it is next to impossible to know, without switching through multiple screens, whether a particular weapon or piece of armor in a shop is an improvment over what your companions are currently using.\n\nI have sunk more hours into the Mount and Blade series in the past couple of years than into every other non-♥♥♥♥♥♥me combined.  If you haven't bough and played it, yet, you are truly missing out on one of the singular gaming experiences of today.

reviewText:
I have thought long about recommending this game, which I played for three years.

So, here we go. Mount&Blade: Warband comes along with Single and Multiplay mode.
Single Player is easily explained: you start out with a rusty blade and a horse. After that you work yourself up from the very bottom of the feudal society to the top. You can become Emperor of Calradia, so, are you ready to accomplish it?
If that is not enough, you can choose one of these tons of mods, which were created for this game. There is something that will fit your taste. They add so much to the game, it's incredible.

The Multiplayer mode is great. There is no other adjective to describe it, I spent over 2000 hours of my life on Multiplayer alone. The skill level, which you can achieve, is fairly comparable to Counter Strike, Warcraft, Starcraft, Dota, League of Legends or any other major eSports title. Mount&Blade Warband comes along with an unique melee fighting system, which allows a lot of moves, tactics and all that other stuff you expect. Various game modes increase the replayability of Multiplayer, although Duel, Siege and Battle would be fairly enough to keep you playing, once you grasped the spirit of this game, for months or like me, for years.
What increases the value of multiplayer again is the fact that this game is kept alive by the community, which developed an active competetive scene with tournaments, leagues and clans.
There are also mods for Multiplayer, with the DLC Napoleonic Wars and cRPG being by far the most popular.

All in all, if you've got the guts to climb the learning wall this game has, it will provide you with an incredible amount of fun, replayability and, probably, addiction.
Mount&Blade franchise games are often reduced, so you can grab them for not much money.

Good luck.

reviewText:
This game may seem simple on the the first glance but due to the various features such as the swordplay and horse combat, the fight always feels fresh and quite enjoyable to the point it gets chaotic swinging and watching enemies fall dead with a spash of blood.

The single player is very detailed with various commander like actions and factions fighting on a large scale map, but this is just a small sample of what is to offer as you can play however you like, being the commander of a large faction driven army or rasing a gang of looters and bandits to raid the lands.

This experience is only made better by the addition of the multiplayer which allows you to fight as one of the various soldier type units that built up the armies that you could make on the singleplayer. There are a vast amount of game types and there are still a large amount of people playing to always be in a 90+ match. I would recommend the Siege gametype as these matches useally have the most players on them.

One of the best games I ever through money at.

reviewText:
This is about the best medieval first/third person game out there. First off you dont really know what the hell youre doing in the Campaign which is a completley open sandbox to do whatever the hell you want. You can become a thief and prey upon poor villagers or merchant caravans or plundering villages on a whim. Or you could be a lord and fight for your king alongside other lords (you also get lands). You could be a king/queen and start your own faction by conquering castles and recruiting lords from other factions or from companions found in taverns. Each faction also has different play styles. The khergits for ex. are 99% horsemen. Whereas the nords are 100% infantry.

But my favorite part about this game is the pvp....IT IS NOT A PAY TO WIN SYSTEM (after all you did pay 15 bucks to get the game) Each game you start with a certain amount of money to buy equipment for a certain class (archer,cavalry,footman) Though the equipment does help in battle youu get money by killing enemies, which gets you better equipment in that one game. Next game your money is reset and then off to the killing fields.

-Got run over by a stray horse
-Got pegged in the face with a throwing axe
-Got kicked off a wall by a teamate
-Kicked that teamate off a wall
-Got impaled by a lance
-Glitched off a siege tower and got blasted to the moon
-Kicked a guy in the nuts and killed him
-Got murdered by a cult of naked men armed with sticks
-Got a headshot across the map
-Got headshotted across the map
-Got brutally murdered by a nord with a giant axe
-Smacked a guy in the face with a mallet
-100/100 would play for eternity

reviewText:
Wow this is a difficult game to describe. A sandbox action RPG set in a medieval land (fantasy, but realistic- no dragons, elves etc). After creating a character and completing a couple of short quests, the world is basically yours to explore and you can play as you please. You get money and/or xp by hunting bandits, pillaging, trading, selling prisoners, fighting tournaments, completing quests... and much more besides.

There are 6 factions all competing for control of the realm. You may decided to ally yourself with one of them, serving the King as a vassal, fighting his wars and seizing towns and castles. You may decided to assist a claimant to the throne, creating a rebel faction to usurp the current King, or you may proclaim youself King and create your own faction. Be aware that this is a dynamic and ever changing world- relations rise and fall, lands are conquered or pillaged, and lords may betray their King and defect. Every action has a consequence.

The game world is presented in a basic overworld map, switching to 3rd person upon entering a town, castle or village, or when in combat. The combat itself is the real meat of the game, allowing the player to swing, thrust or chop depending on the movement of the mouse. Riding on horseback also adds to the fun factor, and learning to time your strike as you gallop towards the enemy is key.
You may also recruit militia and companions into your party, and they will join you on the battlefield. They can be given commands (such as follow, hold and charge) and will also earn xp and level up. The command system is simple, but works well. If you don't want to get blood on your shiny new armour then sending your troops ahead to fight without you is often a legitimate option.

The game does have a few quirks that will annoy some people (such as companions bickering, complaining and abandoning you). Fortunately there is a program available to download (TweakMB) that allows you to easily tailor the gameplay mechanics to better suit you.

Buy this game if you enjoy solid combat, open-ended gameplay and epic battles.

reviewText: You can pretty much do whatever you want in this game. You can start off as a poor noble, and attempt to rise to power and become king. Or you can start off as a merchant and make tons of money buying and reselling your goods. Or you can become a bandit and steal from caravans and the rich and make money to raise your own band of thieves. Whatever you choose to do, Mount and Blade Warband is simply enjoyable to play. Also, there is tons of amazing mods to choose from to enhance the game, completely converting the game into ancient Rome, Japan, or even into the the Colonial period with muskets and all.\n\nThe sheer amount of things to do, and the immense replay value factor makes this game extremely easy to reccomend to all! There is someting for everyone here

You have three options - 1.Join nation and fight for your king   2.Make your own faction and try to capture each castle ( it's the hardest option ) 3.Meet claimants and help them recover their position then fight for them ( for some time they will stay in your party and be your soldier ). You can change it at anytime
helpfulPercent: you can be vassal one day and next day you'll make your own faction or you can help a claimant recover his throne then join a faction and fights against him.\n#2 - Battles = ½\nIt's just a regular battle but if you're cavalry...AI is really stupid

votesTotal: it's easy to outsmart them. commentsCount:
also they will try to move back or charge at you etc.

About units

reviewText:
Lightly grease two baking trays. Pre-heat the oven to 220°C/425°F/Gas 7.

Measure the flour and baking powder into a processor. Add the butter and process until a crumble, then add the sugar. Or make by hand by rubbing  the butter into the flour using your fingertips until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs. Stir in the sugar.

Beat the eggs together until blended and make up to a generous 300ml (1/2 pint) with the milk, then put about 2 tablespoons of the egg/milk aside in a cup for glazing the scones later. Gradually add the egg/milk mixture to the dry ingredients until you have a soft dough. It is far better that the scone mixture is on the wet side, sticking to your fingers, as the scones will rise better.

Turn the dough onto a lightly floured surface and flatten it out with your hand, or use a rolling pin, to a thickness of 1-2 cm (1/2 – ¾ inch). Use a 5 cm (2 inch) fluted cutter to stamp out the dough by pushing the cutter straight down into the dough (as opposed to twisting the cutter) then lift it straight out. This ensures that the scones will rise evenly and keep their shape. Gently push the remaining dough together, knead very lightly then re-roll and cut more scones out as before.

Arrange the scones on the prepared baking trays and brush the tops with the reserved beaten egg/milk mixture to glaze. Bake for about 10-15 minutes or until the scones are well risen and golden. Cool on a wire rack, covered with a clean tea towel to keep them moist. Serve as fresh as possible, cut in half and spread generously with strawberry jam and top with a good spoonful of thick cream.


How to make Scones, I really shouldn't need to persuade you why to buy this. Just do it.
