reviewText:
Charge into battle. Ride into legend. This non-expensive sandbox masterpiece brings together the opportunity to do anything, from being a sellsword bandit mercenary trader to a kingmaking politic-intrigued warband-leading vassal, into strange places such as Calradia's three bickering kingdoms, its adjacent horseloving khanate and the neighbouring haughty sultanate. This game is full of surprises as battlefields change depending on your map's terrain and your party's location.

Inspiring one of the largest modding communities, Mount & Blade holds a great module system which prevents mod conflicts unlike other games (ahem BGS) and lets you fall on your knees to worship the old gods. You could go on an adventure into 1257 where religious war spreads its flame throughout the middle east and engulfs eastern europe, where the golden horde still scours for tribute in places where no king is seated, and where blood and steel would make a peasant into one of his lordships. This module would be one of my personal favorites.

Of course I've left out one of many people's favorites, the multiplayer of Warband. Whether it be cRPG, Napoleonic Wars, or just the native module, the multiplayer experience is enjoyable. Personally, I'm not a big fan of the multiplayer (probably because I don't have anybody to play with) since there are always other games when I want to be competitive. Therefore, I won't say much on multiplayer.

Are you still reading this? Man, you either must be really bored or really skeptical. I would have bought this game right off the bat after I read the words non-expensive sandbox" but you know
date: that's just me. If you're into medieval galore
recommended: this game is a must buy. If you love sandboxes or maybe games which allows you to build armies and lead them into battle
hoursPlayed: this game is definitely for you. If you're into steampunkish or cyberpunkish games like the bioshock series and the fallout series respectively
voteText: then this game might not be for you. But who knows? You might like it."

reviewText:
Been loving this game. Had it on my wish list for some time.. finally got it.
The Native or base game is great. A few mods are great to enhance it even further:
DIPLOMACY Adds a lot of actions to the area of politics, control of fiefs.
MORE WOMEN WITH DIPLOMACY Adds more female options.. HOWEVER.. the story for this is great, and its really fun to have large groups of women, but its a bit to much... every town is practically all women and all fights are led by women. I was looking for a bit more addition of females.. but beyond them taking up the sword for the shortage of men, it becomes amazon territory.  Fun in that aspect.. but not the total aspect I was after.. its not as impressive to be a female leading a band of females if everyone is female...
BRYTANWALD.. must have! Just must have..
Super game overall!
EDIT: Found the Japanese Mod Gekonjo or something. I am brain cramping on the spelling. Anyway. WOW!
EDIT 2: Perisno... best mod of all for me!

reviewText:
I highly recommend this sandbox rpg game where you can be both the commander ordering your troops but also being the kickass slayer in the field while doing that.
Choose your allies, fight for them, or just be a mercenary. Of course you will need an army, so gather recruits, train them into cool wariors trough your harsh training or even faster, from real fights, but that may end up getting some of them killed.
Also don't get too cocky on opponents, especialy if you choose to play realisticaly like i do (no exit without save, thus no loading back at a previous point). Don't forget to feed your troups otherwise they will starve and loose morale, win difficult fights and get morale and renown, bet on yourself and win in tournaments and get gold, participate at feasts, try to impress a lady.
Tired of being a mercenary? Choose a kingdom and swear a vassalage to the king if you have good enogh standing, and get feafs according to your contribution. You choose your way, whatever it may be, depending on what you like.

I suggest buying this game which would get you over 100 hours in singleplayer. How do i know by having just 20 hours till now ? Because i firstly played this game outside of steam. If you are not sure if you will like it, try waiting for a discount.

P.S.: Multiplayer and modability is a + :)

reviewText: I have nothing but good things to say about this game, it is extremely fun, both singleplayer and multiplayer are rewarding and will entertain you with variaty for a long time. reviewText: Great game. In my opinion, it's close to perfect. In the native module single player, the mix between the need for strategy and the way combat works is extemely clever. It's so unique that to compare it to a different game, you would need to compare it to multiple games. The closest I can think of for a single comparasin is a Total War game, but even that isn't not very close. You've got the map and different places you can go to on the map, but when you enter combat you need to comand your whole army as different parts while playing as your character. And that's where the similarities stop. I'd describe the whole game but you can look in the description for that. Don't let the video on the store page fool you. There's so much more to the game than that. It's also very confusing for the first few times you play so don't give up after a few days of playing. Otherwise I just want to recomend the game for anyone out there who likes strategy, medevil, RPG or realistic games at all. Well worth the price.

Mount & Blade : Warband. A great medieval game.
6 factions fight into a war for the honor to conquest Calradia and you are here... in fhe fight... or not.
Play a unique character with a story different ( Soldier, Merchant, Thief ) which has for effect to give you differents caracteristics ( Strengh, Agilty, Intelligence, Charisma ) and skills ( Leader, Looter, Horsery... ).

You can become a Manhunter, a criminal, a mercenary, a merchant, a vassal of a King or maybe YOU will become the King. You can do what you want in this World. Tournaments for earn Denars ( Money of the game ), Quest for earn XP and money, Help Farmer and Citizen or Obey to Lord. Battle of 150 mans for each team, maybe more. It's very awesome. I very request this game. You can pasted hour and hour on this and you can't have two same saves. One unique experience.

reviewText:
The best combat/fighting system of any game I have seen so far. Aside from being able to swing and block from whichever general direction you want, you can also feint, riposte, kick your opponent and knock them down. Fight from foot, or by horse with swords, bows, javelins, crossbows, maces, spears, glaives, cleavers, etc etc.

Unfortunately single player feels a bit incomplete and lacking in some elements. Multiplayer on the other hand is where this game truly excels.

Overall, this is a great game which will provides hundreds of hours of fun. There is also a large modding community which provides custom content (eg: Firearms, new armour, weapons, etc) to this game both in single and multiplayer.

reviewText:
After having pumped 200+ hours into the game I think I should write a review to support the game, so here I go.

Mount & Blade Warband, released in 2010, a kind-of sequel to the original Mount & Blade, is a First/Third Person Action RPG/RTS set in a medieval open world. You set your own goal - live a life as a mercenary, become a Lord of one of the kingdoms, join a claimant to a throne in his battle to take, as he/she thinks, his/her rightful place as king, or go against all of the kingdoms and create your own.
You start the game completely on your own in one of the capital cities of your liking where you happen to get your first quest. You then recruit soldiers for your troop and either be a good samaritan who takes care of the bandits and helps villages, or be the feared vandal by raiding caravans and villages.

Now, putting together your troop and controlling it in battle is where the RTS part comes in.

All your soldiers can be put in groups (similar to ordinary RTS control groups which you select with the 0-9 keys) to always only select those soldiers you want, giving you a lot of control over them. In battles you can give them all sorts of commands you could think of, including, but not limited to, telling them to use only certain weapons that they possess.

Another special thing about this game is the very skill-based combat system.
The melee combat system is based on attacking from four directions and being able to block them - of course by blocking in the direction the swing comes from. This can be really tough sometimes when there's a lot of stuff going on or if your opponent has a rather fast weapon.
You can set up how you want to swing and block independently. Do you want it to work by going into the corresponding direction? Or only by mouse movement?
In singleplayer, for beginners, you can even enable automatic blocking. This will result in you only having to press the block button when a swing comes in, of course you still have to know when to block and when to swing. This setting does not apply to multiplayer though, there it is up to the server wether there's automatic blocking or not - but most likely you'll only be seeing automatic blocking in player vs bot games (there are special modules that are based on fending off enemy waves with other players).

The multiplayer mode is something that first came with Warband, and I think it's pretty solid for an indie game (except for some minor things, but later onto that).
It supports up to 250 players and several modes, including Deathmatch, Team Deathmatch, Capture the Flag, Last man standing Deathmatch and of course castle siege, similar to sieging a castle in singleplayer.

Apart from all that great stuff the game also has an amazing mod support. Search moddb.com for Mount & Blade mods (for both the original game and Warband) and you'll understand what I mean.

As many pros as this game has, it also has a few cons.

A big problem in multiplayer, similar to other games (like Chivalry, for example), are the trolls.

There are a lot of times when you have a lot of fun and fight a bunch of great battles, and then there's the trolls' prime time.
At that time, things are going to get messy. You randomly get hit, shot and kicked by a teammate just to annoy you and then that person just runs along as if nothing happened. When you try to take revenge, they will turn things around and make you look like the vermin, causing everyone to go at you. Classy trolls.
That's about the negatives I could think of and it isn't really the games' fault.



To round this review of, I'll give a short summary:

Pros:
-solid melee combat system
-troop management
-good graphics (remember that this was and still is an indie game - I think the graphics are absolutely fine despite what others have said. Besides, the graphics in M&BII have been improved by a lot.)
-great multiplayer with a high number of players supported and several gamemodes
-mod support
-always challenging

Cons:
-engine limitations

So I come to the conclusion that I can clearly recommend this title to others. Also keep an eye out for the upcoming sequel!

reviewText:
Charge into battle. Ride into legend. This non-expensive sandbox masterpiece brings together the opportunity to do anything, from being a sellsword bandit mercenary trader to a kingmaking politic-intrigued warband-leading vassal, into strange places such as Calradia's three bickering kingdoms, its adjacent horseloving khanate and the neighbouring haughty sultanate. This game is full of surprises as battlefields change depending on your map's terrain and your party's location.

Inspiring one of the largest modding communities, Mount & Blade holds a great module system which prevents mod conflicts unlike other games (ahem BGS) and lets you fall on your knees to worship the old gods. You could go on an adventure into 1257 where religious war spreads its flame throughout the middle east and engulfs eastern europe, where the golden horde still scours for tribute in places where no king is seated, and where blood and steel would make a peasant into one of his lordships. This module would be one of my personal favorites.

Of course I've left out one of many people's favorites, the multiplayer of Warband. Whether it be cRPG, Napoleonic Wars, or just the native module, the multiplayer experience is enjoyable. Personally, I'm not a big fan of the multiplayer (probably because I don't have anybody to play with) since there are always other games when I want to be competitive. Therefore, I won't say much on multiplayer.

Are you still reading this? Man, you either must be really bored or really skeptical. I would have bought this game right off the bat after I read the words non-expensive sandbox" but you know
date: that's just me. If you're into medieval galore
recommended: this game is a must buy. If you love sandboxes or maybe games which allows you to build armies and lead them into battle
hoursPlayed: this game is definitely for you. If you're into steampunkish or cyberpunkish games like the bioshock series and the fallout series respectively
voteText: then this game might not be for you. But who knows? You might like it."

reviewText:
Been loving this game. Had it on my wish list for some time.. finally got it.
The Native or base game is great. A few mods are great to enhance it even further:

MORE WOMEN WITH DIPLOMACY Adds more female options.. HOWEVER.. the story for this is great, and its really fun to have large groups of women, but its a bit to much... every town is practically all women and all fights are led by women. I was looking for a bit more addition of females.. but beyond them taking up the sword for the shortage of men, it becomes amazon territory.  Fun in that aspect.. but not the total aspect I was after.. its not as impressive to be a female leading a band of females if everyone is female...
BRYTANWALD.. must have! Just must have..
Super game overall!
EDIT: Found the Japanese Mod Gekonjo or something. I am brain cramping on the spelling. Anyway. WOW!
EDIT 2: Perisno... best mod of all for me!

reviewText:
Mount & Blade : Warband. A great medieval game.
6 factions fight into a war for the honor to conquest Calradia and you are here... in fhe fight... or not.
Play a unique character with a story different ( Soldier, Merchant, Thief ) which has for effect to give you differents caracteristics ( Strengh, Agilty, Intelligence, Charisma ) and skills ( Leader, Looter, Horsery... ).
And here we are. In Calradia with a poor level 1 but not for long. Personnaly, I go to Sargoth because I love the Realm Of North.  You can become a Manhunter, a criminal, a mercenary, a merchant, a vassal of a King or maybe YOU will become the King. You can do what you want in this World. Tournaments for earn Denars ( Money of the game ), Quest for earn XP and money, Help Farmer and Citizen or Obey to Lord. Battle of 150 mans for each team, maybe more. It's very awesome. I very request this game. You can pasted hour and hour on this and you can't have two same saves. One unique experience.
Besides, a lot of mod are trully impressive and give you a lot of opportunies more than ever.

In this game you can make yourself start off as anything you choose. Easy mode is being a man who grew up being a squire and in noble court and all that, hard mode is being a woman. reviewText:
The Best Medieval game i've ever played by far. What you can do within the games core functions allow you to go on an unique adventure of a gaming life time. The mods integrated in the Steam Workshop also allow for many more hours of play as well as new and interesting ways of playing. YOU ARE THE STORY, every choice you make or every village you pillage is a choice you make. This game can easily get repetitive with combat in some points due to its limited graphical qualities but you are able to take the world. This game is easily a favorite of mine and I would be more than happy to share this game with any of my friends.

Pros: Story
Gameplay
Unique Play style
Hours of replayability
Steam Workshop for easy modding.

Cons: Out dated graphics. (Listed because of the comparison to newer games players will make.)
Clunky Animations (Listed because of the comparison to newer games players will make.)
Limited Voice Acting.
Dull environments(Listed because of the comparison to newer games players will make.)

This game is simply one of the best for its time as well as for it's creative play style and use of mechanics.
I rate this game 8/10 off of my personal expiriences with the game of course.

reviewText:
The best combat/fighting system of any game I have seen so far. Aside from being able to swing and block from whichever general direction you want, you can also feint, riposte, kick your opponent and knock them down. Fight from foot, or by horse with swords, bows, javelins, crossbows, maces, spears, glaives, cleavers, etc etc.

Unfortunately single player feels a bit incomplete and lacking in some elements. Multiplayer on the other hand is where this game truly excels.

Overall, this is a great game which will provides hundreds of hours of fun. There is also a large modding community which provides custom content (eg: Firearms, new armour, weapons, etc) to this game both in single and multiplayer.

I have never played any better game than this one.

reviewText:
Personally I would say this game is a great game, however, I feel there are a few details to know before buying this game. This game was made quite a good number of years ago and therefore the graphics are also a bit outdated so if that is something you can't get over I would not suggest buying this game. Also this game does have a bit steep of a learning curve but once you learn how to play it is definetly worth it.

Now as to why I think this game is so good:
Well first of all there is no story line which some would see as a bad idea but the way Warband uses it, it actually works. It allows for almost any possible course of action to achieve your own personal goals wether it be becoming rich, becoming King, or even marrying a noble lady.
Secondly, the modding community is huge which is constantly adding mods that can increase your experience in the game or even add even more to said experience such as a mod called the Freelance mod which makes it so you are now able to play as a regular soldier in a Lords army.
Thirdly, the multiplayer can have up to 200 players! How many next generation" games do you hear of being able to have 200 players fighting eachother the the death in brutal and bloody combat.
Fourthly
date: there is a DLC for this game which I have taken a particular interest in. This mod is the Napoleonic Wars DLC which allows you to play in multiplayer games as a soldier from the time period of Napoleon conquering Europe. This DLC while not having single player (although there is a mod that is coming out eventually that will have singleplayer) seems to draw you in with its organized communities. While the initial prospect of running around in a line and having to listen to orders may seem daunting especially considering that there is generally no space between each person in a line
recommended: I assure you it is actually a lot more fun then it sounds. Imagine being able to play as a artillery unit that is able to shoot at unit such as that or playing as cavalry and gloriously charging your enemy and cutting down any that get in your way. Or getting a reputation as a deadly sniper as a part of a skirmisher or line infantry regiment. With 200 players able to play in one server at once all these units can all be in the same server working together. So imagine marching towards enemy positions with artillery flying overhead and the cavalry charging past you while the skirmishers snipe important enemy personel."

reviewText:
How do I describe how good Mount and Blade: Warband is? It's difficult to say because it's not the native version of the game itself that is so amazing. Yeah it's fun, and definitely worth the price tag as it is. 60 or so hours worth of fun I would say, but I am rapidly approaching and will definitely surpass the 600 hour mark soon. Why? Because it is like a canvas, the native game introduces gameplay mechanics that have a lot of potential for variety once it's in the hands of the modding community. I'm no modder myself so I can't speak to how hard or easy it is to mod the game, but the general idea of commanding an army on a battlefield in a third or first person perspective lends itself well to a lot of different ways to engage in battle. I had 40-60 hrs in native, another 200 in the viking conquest expansion ($14.95 atm I think) which is a lot of fun and worth the price tag, and the rest in the many various mods of the game. There are mods for just about any sort of warfare from Roman times up to the Civil War. There are mods for fantasy settings and even a LoTR mod. There is so much to offer a person inclined to like this sort of game.

It can be a bit difficult when first learning the game, so don't let that get you down, just look stuff up and keep at it and you'll be engaging in large (in viking conquest at least with troop on field limits of 750 as opposed to the 150 of native) battles. You have to recruit, pay, train, upgrade your units, manage companions, your own character, villages, towns, castles, and even a kingdom later on if you manage to establish yourself. It's a bit to learn and sometimes it is hard early on to get a foothold, but the game is worth the time getting to know it. The actual combat seems stange at first, but becomes rather intuitive once you get a handle on it, and having tested all the weapon types, they're all useful in one situation or another, but I tend to learn towards swords and pole-arms as being mounted is important for a commander and those weapons lend well to such combat. Archery is fun, too, but that takes a lot of practice to be viable.

I rate gameplay 10/10, look to other reviews for other factors like graphics because as long as I know what I'm looking at, graphics quality doesn't mean so much to me.

reviewText:
I highly recommend this sandbox rpg game where you can be both the commander ordering your troops but also being the kickass slayer in the field while doing that.
Choose your allies, fight for them, or just be a mercenary. Of course you will need an army, so gather recruits, train them into cool wariors trough your harsh training or even faster, from real fights, but that may end up getting some of them killed.
Also don't get too cocky on opponents, especialy if you choose to play realisticaly like i do (no exit without save, thus no loading back at a previous point). Don't forget to feed your troups otherwise they will starve and loose morale, win difficult fights and get morale and renown, bet on yourself and win in tournaments and get gold, participate at feasts, try to impress a lady.
Tired of being a mercenary? Choose a kingdom and swear a vassalage to the king if you have good enogh standing, and get feafs according to your contribution. You choose your way, whatever it may be, depending on what you like.

I suggest buying this game which would get you over 100 hours in singleplayer. How do i know by having just 20 hours till now ? Because i firstly played this game outside of steam. If you are not sure if you will like it, try waiting for a discount.

P.S.: Multiplayer and modability is a + :)

reviewText: I have nothing but good things to say about this game, it is extremely fun, both singleplayer and multiplayer are rewarding and will entertain you with variaty for a long time. Additionally it is extremely moddable and has integrated steam workshop. Adding a mod is usually as simple as dragging a file into another file. Single player is very open ended and will satisfy people looking for experiences as a merchant, a bandit, a bandit hunter, an assassin, a lord under a kings court, a rebel or even a king or a queen to name a few. In fact if you wanted to you could scrape out a living as a royal messenger or with the help of mods as a lowly soldier.\n\nAll in all all three games were a great investment for me and kept me busy many a lonely or slow moving night.

reviewText: I love this game. I've played Mount and Blade since the very first (beta) version and loved it since. It is a sandbox game. If you are into adventure,  and having your own career, then get this game. You can play Multiplayer, Single Player, Custom Battle, and there are also mods which you can install. My favorite feature would probably be  Multiplayer. You can meet other people who play this game, and be friends with them on Steam! You can also create and join Multiplayer clans, and much more. If I could rate this game on a scale of 1-10, it would definitely be a 10.

reviewText:
Note: I have been away from this game for a small amount of time, so excuse me if some of the information I give you is incorrect.

General
If you don't like medieval games, this game is the last thing you'd want. This game is both third person and first person. There are 3 main classes with every unit in the game, including in multiplayer. The three classes are  Infantry, Archers, and Horseman.  the weapon usage varies with each class. The factions are  Vaegirs, Rhodoks, Swadians, Sarranids, Nords, and Khergits.  These factions are constantly at war with each other. You can affect the game in a massive way, or a small way. In both singleplayer and multiplayer, people can affect you and you can affect people in a variety of ways. From covering an archer as an infantry class to covering infantry as a horseman class, the customization is a great part of the game. The graphics are obviously not the best, but that's just what you get with an older game. Don't let that control your whole opinion of the game. There are no real spoilers to the game, as there is no hand-holding, or missions". There are quests
date:
but you can choose to take them.

Singleplayer
Singleplayer is a great part of the game that not many people will get bored of right after starting. You start out with a small band of men that are only able to defeat bandits
recommended: which can eventually turn into a 300 man army attacking a rival king. You have the choice to do whatever you want. If you allign to a faction for the purpose of destroying it

or just work your way up by taking a city by yourself.

Single player is very open ended and will satisfy people looking for experiences as a merchant, a bandit, a bandit hunter, an assassin, a lord under a kings court, a rebel or even a king or a queen to name a few. In fact if you wanted to you could scrape out a living as a royal messenger or with the help of mods as a lowly soldier.\n\nAll in all all three games were a great investment for me and kept me busy many a lonely or slow moving night.

reviewText: For those of you who like RTS games, this will change how you look at them. Never before the Mount&Blade series could you command your troops while actually fighting the battle. Mount&Blade Warband is the perfect mixture of Real Time Strategy, Fighting game, with a hint of sandbox in there. If you are looking for a great Real Time Strategy experience, you should definetly consider this game.
